hints.content:
An $\blueE{\text{even}}$ number is a number that can be split into $2$ equal groups.

We find $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers by making sure every object in the group has a pair.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9d50cd961bb1ee962eb60cc708a5e737e9d4486c)

Examples of $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers are $\blueE2, \blueE4,\blueE6, \blueE8, \blueE{10},  . .  .$

An $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number **cannot** be split into $2$ equal groups. 

We find $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers by trying to pair objects and finding there is **not** always a pair.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/10c3af09ebfcd0c6d05b4edd219f33894cc4d8b9)

Examples of $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers are $\maroonD1, \maroonD3, \maroonD5, \maroonD7, \maroonD9, . . . $

In this image, there are $\maroonD7$ pigs.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/b4fa182e48b6c60c3d1998258bc94d03fbfa05f0)

Each pig does **not** have a pair, so there are an odd number of pigs.

In this image, there are $\blueE6$ eggs.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/4550571e0d12949615f1617fbd913437f9db7658)

Each egg has a pair, so there are an even number of eggs.

In this image, there are $\maroonD3$ sharks.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/7d7f96c886eed31d1e24590b1a8f17eafa033759)

Each shark does **not** have a pair, so there are an odd number of sharks.

Here is the completed table:

Image | Even/Odd
- | - | -
![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/89e0d9b412aeedb876f0f6885c904a5054bdde5d) | **Odd**
![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/cf958c80fbfec114f3aeabc9a2c54d2db9803623) | **Even**
![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/591e2da531e474dd1dcc419d7bf818a27fd90f99)  | **Odd**

question.content:
